     335                 :            : 
     336                 :            :     // Predicate to use for filtering transactions in removeForReorg.
     337                 :            :     // Checks whether the transaction is still final and, if it spends a coinbase output, mature.
     338                 :            :     // Also updates valid entries' cached LockPoints if needed.
     339                 :            :     // If false, the tx is still valid and its lockpoints are updated.
     340                 :            :     // If true, the tx would be invalid in the next block; remove this entry and all of its descendants.
     341                 :            :     // Note that v3 rules are not applied here, so reorgs may cause violations of v3 inheritance or
     342                 :            :     // topology restrictions.

     386                 :            :     // We also need to remove any now-immature transactions

     388                 :            :     // Re-limit mempool size, in case we added any transactions
     389   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :     LimitMempoolSize(*m_mempool, this->CoinsTip());
     390                 :          0 : }
     391                 :            : 
     392                 :            : /**
     393                 :            : * Checks to avoid mempool polluting consensus critical paths since cached
     394                 :            : * signature and script validity results will be reused if we validate this
     395                 :            : * transaction again during block validation.
     396                 :            : * */

     448                 :            :     // around easier.

     456                 :            :          * acceptance. This allows the caller to optionally remove the cache

     560                 :            : 
     561                 :            :     /**

     563                 :            :     * conflict with each other, and the transactions cannot already be in the mempool. Parents must
     564                 :            :     * come before children if any dependencies exist.
     565                 :            :     */

     572                 :            :      * (m_allow_replacement), and creates a PackageMempoolAcceptResult wrapping the result.

     640                 :            :     // Run the policy checks on a given transaction, excluding any script checks.
     641                 :            :     // Looks up inputs, calculates feerate, considers replacement, evaluates
     642                 :            :     // package limits, etc. As this function can be invoked for "free" by a peer,
     643                 :            :     // only tests that are fast should be done here (to avoid CPU DoS).

     645                 :            :

     650                 :            :     // ancestor/descendant limits done in PreChecks).

     656                 :            :     // only invoke this on transactions that have otherwise passed policy checks.

     660                 :            :     // result in the scriptcache. This should be done after

     662                 :            :     // utxo set or in the mempool.

     670                 :            :     // Submit all transactions to the mempool and call ConsensusScriptChecks to add to the script

     898                 :            :     // Note that these modifications are only applicable to single transaction scenarios;
     899                 :            :     // carve-outs and package RBF are disabled for multi-transaction evaluations.
     900                 :     100977 :     CTxMemPool::Limits maybe_rbf_limits = m_pool.m_limits;
     901                 :            : 
     902                 :            :     // Calculate in-mempool ancestors, up to a limit.
     903         [ +  + ]:     100977 :     if (ws.m_conflicts.size() == 1) {
     904                 :            :         // In general, when we receive an RBF transaction with mempool conflicts, we want to know whether we
     905                 :            :         // would meet the chain limits after the conflicts have been removed. However, there isn't a practical
     906         [ +  - ]:       1349 :         // way to do this short of calculating the ancestor and descendant sets with an overlay cache of
     907                 :            :         // changed mempool entries. Due to both implementation and runtime complexity concerns, this isn't
     908                 :            :         // very realistic, thus we only ensure a limited set of transactions are RBF'able despite mempool
     909                 :            :         // conflicts here. Importantly, we need to ensure that some transactions which were accepted using
     910                 :            :         // the below carve-out are able to be RBF'ed, without impacting the security the carve-out provides
     911                 :            :         // for off-chain contract systems (see link in the comment below).
     912                 :            :         //
     913                 :            :         // Specifically, the subset of RBF transactions which we allow despite chain limits are those which
     914                 :            :         // conflict directly with exactly one other transaction (but may evict children of said transaction),
     915                 :            :         // and which are not adding any new mempool dependencies. Note that the "no new mempool dependencies"
     916                 :            :         // check is accomplished later, so we don't bother doing anything about it here, but if our
     917                 :            :         // policy changes, we may need to move that check to here instead of removing it wholesale.
     918                 :            :         //
     919                 :            :         // Such transactions are clearly not merging any existing packages, so we are only concerned with
     920                 :            :         // ensuring that (a) no package is growing past the package size (not count) limits and (b) we are
     921                 :            :         // not allowing something to effectively use the (below) carve-out spot when it shouldn't be allowed
     922                 :            :         // to.
     923                 :            :         //
     924                 :            :         // To check these we first check if we meet the RBF criteria, above, and increment the descendant
     925                 :            :         // limits by the direct conflict and its descendants (as these are recalculated in
     926                 :            :         // CalculateMempoolAncestors by assuming the new transaction being added is a new descendant, with no
     927                 :            :         // removals, of each parent's existing dependent set). The ancestor count limits are unmodified (as
     928                 :            :         // the ancestor limits should be the same for both our new transaction and any conflicts).
     929                 :       1349 :         // We don't bother incrementing m_limit_descendants by the full removal count as that limit never comes
     930                 :            :         // into force here (as we're only adding a single transaction).
     931         [ +  - ]:      30734 :         assert(ws.m_iters_conflicting.size() == 1);

     938         [ +  - ]:     100977 :     auto ancestors{m_pool.CalculateMemPoolAncestors(*entry, maybe_rbf_limits)};

     940                 :            :         // If CalculateMemPoolAncestors fails second time, we want the original error string.
     941                 :            :         // Contracting/payment channels CPFP carve-out:
     942                 :            :         // If the new transaction is relatively small (up to 40k weight)
     943                 :            :         // and has at most one ancestor (ie ancestor limit of 2, including
     944                 :            :         // the new transaction), allow it if its parent has exactly the
     945                 :            :         // descendant limit descendants.
     946                 :            :         //
     947                 :            :         // This allows protocols which rely on distrusting counterparties
     948                 :            :         // being able to broadcast descendants of an unconfirmed transaction
     949                 :            :         // to be secure by simply only having two immediately-spendable
     950                 :            :         // outputs - one for each counterparty. For more info on the uses for

    1003                 :            : 
    1004                 :      32046 : bool MemPoolAccept::ReplacementChecks(Workspace& ws)
    1005                 :            : {
    1006                 :      32046 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1007                 :      32046 :     AssertLockHeld(m_pool.cs);
    1008                 :            : 
    1009                 :      32046 :     const CTransaction& tx = *ws.m_ptx;
    1010                 :      32046 :     const uint256& hash = ws.m_hash;
    1011                 :      32046 :     TxValidationState& state = ws.m_state;
    1012                 :            : 
    1013                 :      32046 :     CFeeRate newFeeRate(ws.m_modified_fees, ws.m_vsize);
    1014                 :            :     // Enforce Rule #6. The replacement transaction must have a higher feerate than its direct conflicts.
    1015                 :            :     // - The motivation for this check is to ensure that the replacement transaction is preferable for
    1016                 :            :     //   block-inclusion, compared to what would be removed from the mempool.
    1017                 :       1349 :     // - This logic predates ancestor feerate-based transaction selection, which is why it doesn't
    1018                 :            :     //   consider feerates of descendants.
    1019                 :            :     // - Note: Ancestor feerate-based transaction selection has made this comparison insufficient to
    1020                 :            :     //   guarantee that this is incentive-compatible for miners, because it is possible for a
    1021                 :       1349 :     //   descendant transaction of a direct conflict to pay a higher feerate than the transaction that
    1022                 :            :     //   might replace them, under these rules.
    1023   [ +  +  +  + ]:      54430 :     if (const auto err_string{PaysMoreThanConflicts(ws.m_iters_conflicting, newFeeRate, hash)}) {
    1024                 :            :         // Even though this is a fee-related failure, this result is TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY, not
    1025                 :       1349 :         // TX_RECONSIDERABLE, because it cannot be bypassed using package validation.
    1026                 :            :         // This must be changed if package RBF is enabled.
    1027         [ +  - ]:      22384 :         return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY,
    1028         [ +  - ]:      22384 :                              strprintf("insufficient fee%s", ws.m_sibling_eviction ? " (including sibling eviction)" : ""), *err_string);
    1029                 :            :     }
    1030                 :            : 
    1031                 :            :     // Calculate all conflicting entries and enforce Rule #5.
    1032   [ -  +  -  + ]:       9662 :     if (const auto err_string{GetEntriesForConflicts(tx, m_pool, ws.m_iters_conflicting, ws.m_all_conflicting)}) {
    1033         [ #  # ]:          0 :         return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY,
    1034         [ #  # ]:          0 :                              strprintf("too many potential replacements%s", ws.m_sibling_eviction ? " (including sibling eviction)" : ""), *err_string);
    1035                 :            :     }
    1036                 :            :     // Enforce Rule #2.
    1037   [ +  +  +  + ]:      10934 :     if (const auto err_string{HasNoNewUnconfirmed(tx, m_pool, ws.m_iters_conflicting)}) {
    1038                 :            :         // Sibling eviction is only done for v3 transactions, which cannot have multiple ancestors.
    1039         [ +  - ]:       1272 :         Assume(!ws.m_sibling_eviction);
    1040         [ +  - ]:       1272 :         return state.Invalid(TxValidationResult::TX_MEMPOOL_POLICY,

    1115                 :            :     // Check again against the current block tip's script verification
    1116                 :            :     // flags to cache our script execution flags. This is, of course,
    1117                 :            :     // useless if the next block has different script flags from the
    1118                 :            :     // previous one, but because the cache tracks script flags for us it
    1119                 :            :     // will auto-invalidate and we'll just have a few blocks of extra
    1120                 :            :     // misses on soft-fork activation.
    1121                 :            :     //
    1122                 :            :     // This is also useful in case of bugs in the standard flags that cause
    1123                 :            :     // transactions to pass as valid when they're actually invalid. For
    1124                 :            :     // instance the STRICTENC flag was incorrectly allowing certain
    1125                 :            :     // CHECKSIG NOT scripts to pass, even though they were invalid.
    1126                 :            :     //
    1127                 :            :     // There is a similar check in CreateNewBlock() to prevent creating
    1128                 :            :     // invalid blocks (using TestBlockValidity), however allowing such
    1129                 :            :     // transactions into the mempool can be exploited as a DoS attack.
    1130                 :      40737 :     unsigned int currentBlockScriptVerifyFlags{GetBlockScriptFlags(*m_active_chainstate.m_chain.Tip(), m_active_chainstate.m_chainman)};

    1347                 :            :         }

    1362                 :            :         }
    1363         [ +  + ]:       5261 :     }
    1364                 :            : 
    1365                 :            :     // Transactions must meet two minimum feerates: the mempool minimum fee and min relay fee.
    1366                 :            :     // For transactions consisting of exactly one child and its parents, it suffices to use the
    1367                 :            :     // package feerate (total modified fees / total virtual size) to check this requirement.
    1368                 :            :     // Note that this is an aggregate feerate; this function has not checked that there are transactions
    1369                 :            :     // too low feerate to pay for themselves, or that the child transactions are higher feerate than
    1370                 :            :     // their parents. Using aggregate feerate may allow "parents pay for child" behavior and permit
    1371                 :            :     // a child that is below mempool minimum feerate. To avoid these behaviors, callers of
    1372                 :            :     // AcceptMultipleTransactions need to restrict txns topology (e.g. to ancestor sets) and check
    1373                 :            :     // the feerates of individuals and subsets.
    1374         [ +  - ]:       4719 :     const auto m_total_vsize = std::accumulate(workspaces.cbegin(), workspaces.cend(), int64_t{0},

    1428                 :            : 
    1429                 :      11782 : void MemPoolAccept::CleanupTemporaryCoins()
    1430                 :            : {
    1431                 :            :     // There are 3 kinds of coins in m_view:
    1432                 :            :     // (1) Temporary coins from the transactions in subpackage, constructed by m_viewmempool.
    1433                 :            :     // (2) Mempool coins from transactions in the mempool, constructed by m_viewmempool.
    1434                 :            :     // (3) Confirmed coins fetched from our current UTXO set.
    1435                 :            :     //
    1436                 :            :     // (1) Temporary coins need to be removed, regardless of whether the transaction was submitted.
    1437                 :            :     // If the transaction was submitted to the mempool, m_viewmempool will be able to fetch them from
    1438                 :            :     // there. If it wasn't submitted to mempool, it is incorrect to keep them - future calls may try
    1439                 :            :     // to spend those coins that don't actually exist.
    1440                 :            :     // (2) Mempool coins also need to be removed. If the mempool contents have changed as a result
    1441                 :            :     // of submitting or replacing transactions, coins previously fetched from mempool may now be
    1442                 :            :     // spent or nonexistent. Those coins need to be deleted from m_view.
    1443                 :            :     // (3) Confirmed coins don't need to be removed. The chainstate has not changed (we are
    1444                 :            :     // holding cs_main and no blocks have been processed) so the confirmed tx cannot disappear like
    1445                 :            :     // a mempool tx can. The coin may now be spent after we submitted a tx to mempool, but
    1446                 :            :     // we have already checked that the package does not have 2 transactions spending the same coin.
    1447                 :            :     // Keeping them in m_view is an optimization to not re-fetch confirmed coins if we later look up
    1448                 :            :     // inputs for this transaction again.
    1449         [ +  + ]:      37905 :     for (const auto& outpoint : m_viewmempool.GetNonBaseCoins()) {
    1450                 :            :         // In addition to resetting m_viewmempool, we also need to manually delete these coins from
    1451                 :            :         // m_view because it caches copies of the coins it fetched from m_viewmempool previously.
    1452         [ +  - ]:      26123 :         m_view.Uncache(outpoint);
    1453                 :      26123 :     }
    1454                 :            :     // This deletes the temporary and mempool coins.
    1455                 :      11782 :     m_viewmempool.Reset();
    1456                 :      11782 : }
    1457                 :            : 
    1458                 :      11782 : PackageMempoolAcceptResult MemPoolAccept::AcceptSubPackage(const std::vector<CTransactionRef>& subpackage, ATMPArgs& args)
    1459                 :            : {
    1460                 :      11782 :     AssertLockHeld(::cs_main);

    1471   [ +  -  +  -  :       7577 :             package_state_wrapped.Invalid(PackageValidationResult::PCKG_TX, "transaction failed");
                   -  + ]
    1472                 :       7577 :         }

    1475                 :            : 
    1476                 :            :     // Clean up m_view and m_viewmempool so that other subpackage evaluations don't have access to
    1477                 :            :     // coins they shouldn't. Keep some coins in order to minimize re-fetching coins from the UTXO set.

    1479                 :            :

    1481         [ +  - ]:      11782 : }

    1483                 :      18755 : PackageMempoolAcceptResult MemPoolAccept::AcceptPackage(const Package& package, ATMPArgs& args)
    1484                 :            : {
    1485                 :      18755 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    1486                 :            :     // Used if returning a PackageMempoolAcceptResult directly from this function.
    1487                 :      18755 :     PackageValidationState package_state_quit_early;
    1488                 :            : 
    1489                 :            :     // Check that the package is well-formed. If it isn't, we won't try to validate any of the
    1490                 :            :     // transactions and thus won't return any MempoolAcceptResults, just a package-wide error.
    1491                 :            : 
    1492                 :            :     // Context-free package checks.
    1493   [ +  -  +  + ]:      18755 :     if (!IsWellFormedPackage(package, package_state_quit_early, /*require_sorted=*/true)) {
    1494   [ +  -  +  - ]:      10740 :         return PackageMempoolAcceptResult(package_state_quit_early, {});
    1495                 :            :     }
    1496                 :            : 
    1497                 :            :     // All transactions in the package must be a parent of the last transaction. This is just an
    1498                 :            :     // opportunity for us to fail fast on a context-free check without taking the mempool lock.
    1499   [ +  -  +  + ]:       8015 :     if (!IsChildWithParents(package)) {

    1502                 :            :     }
    1503                 :            : 
    1504                 :            :     // IsChildWithParents() guarantees the package is > 1 transactions.
    1505         [ +  - ]:       7210 :     assert(package.size() > 1);

    1507                 :            :     // be sorted, so the last transaction is the child.

    1511         [ +  - ]:       7210 :                    std::inserter(unconfirmed_parent_txids, unconfirmed_parent_txids.end()),
    1512                 :       7434 :                    [](const auto& tx) { return tx->GetHash(); });
    1513                 :            : 
    1514                 :            :     // All child inputs must refer to a preceding package transaction or a confirmed UTXO. The only
    1515                 :            :     // way to verify this is to look up the child's inputs in our current coins view (not including
    1516                 :            :     // mempool), and enforce that all parents not present in the package be available at chain tip.
    1517                 :            :     // Since this check can bring new coins into the coins cache, keep track of these coins and
    1518                 :            :     // uncache them if we don't end up submitting this package to the mempool.
    1519         [ +  - ]:       7210 :     const CCoinsViewCache& coins_tip_cache = m_active_chainstate.CoinsTip();

    1551         [ +  - ]:      11152 :         const auto& wtxid = tx->GetWitnessHash();
    1552                 :      11152 :         const auto& txid = tx->GetHash();
    1553                 :            :         // There are 3 possibilities: already in mempool, same-txid-diff-wtxid already in mempool,
    1554                 :            :         // or not in mempool. An already confirmed tx is treated as one not in mempool, because all
    1555                 :            :         // we know is that the inputs aren't available.
    1556   [ +  -  +  -  :      11152 :         if (m_pool.exists(GenTxid::Wtxid(wtxid))) {
                   +  + ]
    1557                 :            :             // Exact transaction already exists in the mempool.
    1558                 :            :             // Node operators are free to set their mempool policies however they please, nodes may receive
    1559                 :            :             // transactions in different orders, and malicious counterparties may try to take advantage of
    1560                 :            :             // policy differences to pin or delay propagation of transactions. As such, it's possible for
    1561                 :            :             // some package transaction(s) to already be in the mempool, and we don't want to reject the
    1562                 :            :             // entire package in that case (as that could be a censorship vector). De-duplicate the
    1563                 :            :             // transactions that are already in the mempool, and only call AcceptMultipleTransactions() with
    1564                 :            :             // the new transactions. This ensures we don't double-count transaction counts and sizes when
    1565                 :            :             // checking ancestor/descendant limits, or double-count transaction fees for fee-related policy.
    1566   [ +  -  +  - ]:         77 :             const auto& entry{*Assert(m_pool.GetEntry(txid))};

    1592                 :            :                 // of feerate. For example, if a transaction fails here due to violation of a
    1593                 :            :                 // consensus rule, the result will not change when it is submitted as part of a
    1594                 :            :                 // package. To minimize the amount of repeated work, unless the transaction fails
    1595                 :            :                 // due to feerate or missing inputs (its parent is a previous transaction in the
    1596                 :            :                 // package that failed due to feerate), don't run package validation. Note that this
    1597                 :            :                 // decision might not make sense if different types of packages are allowed in the

    1616   [ +  -  +  - ]:       5466 :     LimitMempoolSize(m_pool, m_active_chainstate.CoinsTip());

    1902                 :       1402 : bool InitScriptExecutionCache(size_t max_size_bytes)
    1903                 :            : {
    1904                 :            :     // Setup the salted hasher
    1905                 :       1402 :     uint256 nonce = GetRandHash();
    1906                 :            :     // We want the nonce to be 64 bytes long to force the hasher to process
    1907                 :            :     // this chunk, which makes later hash computations more efficient. We
    1908                 :            :     // just write our 32-byte entropy twice to fill the 64 bytes.
    1909                 :       1402 :     g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher.Write(nonce.begin(), 32);
    1910                 :       1402 :     g_scriptExecutionCacheHasher.Write(nonce.begin(), 32);
    1911                 :            : 
    1912                 :       1402 :     auto setup_results = g_scriptExecutionCache.setup_bytes(max_size_bytes);
    1913         [ -  + ]:       1402 :     if (!setup_results) return false;
    1914                 :            : 
    1915                 :       4206 :     const auto [num_elems, approx_size_bytes] = *setup_results;
    1916   [ +  -  +  -  :       1402 :     LogPrintf("Using %zu MiB out of %zu MiB requested for script execution cache, able to store %zu elements\n",

    1918                 :       1402 :     return true;
    1919                 :       1402 : }
    1920                 :            : 
    1921                 :            : /**
    1922                 :            :  * Check whether all of this transaction's input scripts succeed.
    1923                 :            :  *
    1924                 :            :  * This involves ECDSA signature checks so can be computationally intensive. This function should
    1925                 :            :  * only be called after the cheap sanity checks in CheckTxInputs passed.
    1926                 :            :  *
    1927                 :            :  * If pvChecks is not nullptr, script checks are pushed onto it instead of being performed inline. Any
    1928                 :            :  * script checks which are not necessary (eg due to script execution cache hits) are, obviously,
    1929                 :            :  * not pushed onto pvChecks/run.
    1930                 :            :  *
    1931                 :            :  * Setting cacheSigStore/cacheFullScriptStore to false will remove elements from the corresponding cache
    1932                 :            :  * which are matched. This is useful for checking blocks where we will likely never need the cache
    1933                 :            :  * entry again.
    1934                 :            :  *
    1935                 :            :  * Note that we may set state.reason to NOT_STANDARD for extra soft-fork flags in flags, block-checking
    1936                 :            :  * callers should probably reset it to CONSENSUS in such cases.
    1937                 :            :  *
    1938                 :            :  * Non-static (and re-declared) in src/test/txvalidationcache_tests.cpp
    1939                 :            :  */
    1940                 :     118453 : bool CheckInputScripts(const CTransaction& tx, TxValidationState& state,
    1941                 :            :                        const CCoinsViewCache& inputs, unsigned int flags, bool cacheSigStore,
    1942                 :            :                        bool cacheFullScriptStore, PrecomputedTransactionData& txdata,
    1943                 :            :                        std::vector<CScriptCheck>* pvChecks)
    1944                 :            : {
    1945         [ -  + ]:     118453 :     if (tx.IsCoinBase()) return true;
    1946                 :            : 
    1947         [ +  + ]:     118453 :     if (pvChecks) {
    1948                 :      10864 :         pvChecks->reserve(tx.vin.size());
    1949                 :      10864 :     }
    1950                 :            : 
    1951                 :            :     // First check if script executions have been cached with the same
    1952                 :            :     // flags. Note that this assumes that the inputs provided are

    2220                 :            :  *  can fail if those validity checks fail (among other reasons). */
    2221                 :     135325 : bool Chainstate::ConnectBlock(const CBlock& block, BlockValidationState& state, CBlockIndex* pindex,
    2222                 :            :                                CCoinsViewCache& view, bool fJustCheck)
    2223                 :            : {
    2224                 :     135325 :     AssertLockHeld(cs_main);
    2225         [ +  - ]:     135325 :     assert(pindex);
    2226                 :            : 
    2227                 :     135325 :     uint256 block_hash{block.GetHash()};
    2228         [ +  - ]:     135325 :     assert(*pindex->phashBlock == block_hash);
    2229                 :     135325 :     const bool parallel_script_checks{m_chainman.GetCheckQueue().HasThreads()};
    2230                 :            : 
    2231                 :     135325 :     const auto time_start{SteadyClock::now()};
    2232                 :     135325 :     const CChainParams& params{m_chainman.GetParams()};
    2233                 :            : 
    2234                 :            :     // Check it again in case a previous version let a bad block in
    2235                 :            :     // NOTE: We don't currently (re-)invoke ContextualCheckBlock() or
    2236                 :            :     // ContextualCheckBlockHeader() here. This means that if we add a new
    2237                 :            :     // consensus rule that is enforced in one of those two functions, then we
    2238                 :            :     // may have let in a block that violates the rule prior to updating the
    2239                 :            :     // software, and we would NOT be enforcing the rule here. Fully solving
    2240                 :            :     // upgrade from one software version to the next after a consensus rule
    2241                 :            :     // change is potentially tricky and issue-specific (see NeedsRedownload()
    2242                 :            :     // for one approach that was used for BIP 141 deployment).
    2243                 :            :     // Also, currently the rule against blocks more than 2 hours in the future
    2244                 :            :     // is enforced in ContextualCheckBlockHeader(); we wouldn't want to
    2245                 :            :     // re-enforce that rule here (at least until we make it impossible for
    2246                 :            :     // the clock to go backward).
    2247         [ +  - ]:     135325 :     if (!CheckBlock(block, state, params.GetConsensus(), !fJustCheck, !fJustCheck)) {
    2248         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (state.GetResult() == BlockValidationResult::BLOCK_MUTATED) {
    2249                 :            :             // We don't write down blocks to disk if they may have been
    2250                 :            :             // corrupted, so this should be impossible unless we're having hardware
    2251                 :            :             // problems.
    2252   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             return FatalError(m_chainman.GetNotifications(), state, "Corrupt block found indicating potential hardware failure; shutting down");
    2253                 :            :         }
    2254   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :         LogError("%s: Consensus::CheckBlock: %s\n", __func__, state.ToString());

    2256                 :            :     }

    2261                 :            :

    2263                 :            : 
    2264                 :            :     // Special case for the genesis block, skipping connection of its transactions
    2265                 :            :     // (its coinbase is unspendable)
    2266         [ +  + ]:     135325 :     if (block_hash == params.GetConsensus().hashGenesisBlock) {
    2267         [ -  + ]:       1349 :         if (!fJustCheck)
    2268                 :       1349 :             view.SetBestBlock(pindex->GetBlockHash());
    2269                 :       1349 :         return true;
    2270                 :            :     }
    2271                 :            : 
    2272                 :     133976 :     bool fScriptChecks = true;
    2273         [ +  - ]:     133976 :     if (!m_chainman.AssumedValidBlock().IsNull()) {
    2274                 :            :         // We've been configured with the hash of a block which has been externally verified to have a valid history.
    2275                 :            :         // A suitable default value is included with the software and updated from time to time.  Because validity
    2276                 :            :         //  relative to a piece of software is an objective fact these defaults can be easily reviewed.
    2277                 :            :         // This setting doesn't force the selection of any particular chain but makes validating some faster by
    2278                 :            :         //  effectively caching the result of part of the verification.
    2279                 :          0 :         BlockMap::const_iterator it{m_blockman.m_block_index.find(m_chainman.AssumedValidBlock())};
    2280         [ #  # ]:          0 :         if (it != m_blockman.m_block_index.end()) {
    2281   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :             if (it->second.GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    2282         [ #  # ]:          0 :                 m_chainman.m_best_header->GetAncestor(pindex->nHeight) == pindex &&
    2283                 :          0 :                 m_chainman.m_best_header->nChainWork >= m_chainman.MinimumChainWork()) {
    2284                 :            :                 // This block is a member of the assumed verified chain and an ancestor of the best header.
    2285                 :            :                 // Script verification is skipped when connecting blocks under the
    2286                 :            :                 // assumevalid block. Assuming the assumevalid block is valid this
    2287                 :            :                 // is safe because block merkle hashes are still computed and checked,
    2288                 :            :                 // Of course, if an assumed valid block is invalid due to false scriptSigs
    2289                 :            :                 // this optimization would allow an invalid chain to be accepted.
    2290                 :            :                 // The equivalent time check discourages hash power from extorting the network via DOS attack
    2291                 :            :                 //  into accepting an invalid block through telling users they must manually set assumevalid.
    2292                 :            :                 //  Requiring a software change or burying the invalid block, regardless of the setting, makes
    2293                 :            :                 //  it hard to hide the implication of the demand.  This also avoids having release candidates
    2294                 :            :                 //  that are hardly doing any signature verification at all in testing without having to
    2295                 :            :                 //  artificially set the default assumed verified block further back.
    2296                 :            :                 // The test against the minimum chain work prevents the skipping when denied access to any chain at
    2297                 :            :                 //  least as good as the expected chain.
    2298                 :          0 :                 fScriptChecks = (GetBlockProofEquivalentTime(*m_chainman.m_best_header, *pindex, *m_chainman.m_best_header, params.GetConsensus()) <= 60 * 60 * 24 * 7 * 2);
    2299                 :          0 :             }
    2300                 :          0 :         }
    2301                 :          0 :     }
    2302                 :            : 
    2303                 :     133976 :     const auto time_1{SteadyClock::now()};
    2304                 :     133976 :     time_check += time_1 - time_start;
    2305   [ +  +  +  -  :     133976 :     LogPrint(BCLog::BENCH, "    - Sanity checks: %.2fms [%.2fs (%.2fms/blk)]\n",
          +  -  +  -  +  
          -  +  -  +  -  
                   +  - ]
    2306                 :            :              Ticks<MillisecondsDouble>(time_1 - time_start),
    2307                 :            :              Ticks<SecondsDouble>(time_check),
    2308                 :            :              Ticks<MillisecondsDouble>(time_check) / num_blocks_total);
    2309                 :            : 
    2310                 :            :     // Do not allow blocks that contain transactions which 'overwrite' older transactions,
    2311                 :            :     // unless those are already completely spent.
    2312                 :            :     // If such overwrites are allowed, coinbases and transactions depending upon those
    2313                 :            :     // can be duplicated to remove the ability to spend the first instance -- even after
    2314                 :            :     // being sent to another address.
    2315                 :            :     // See BIP30, CVE-2012-1909, and http://r6.ca/blog/20120206T005236Z.html for more information.
    2316                 :            :     // This rule was originally applied to all blocks with a timestamp after March 15, 2012, 0:00 UTC.
    2317                 :            :     // Now that the whole chain is irreversibly beyond that time it is applied to all blocks except the
    2318                 :            :     // two in the chain that violate it. This prevents exploiting the issue against nodes during their
    2319                 :            :     // initial block download.
    2320                 :     133976 :     bool fEnforceBIP30 = !IsBIP30Repeat(*pindex);
    2321                 :            : 
    2322                 :            :     // Once BIP34 activated it was not possible to create new duplicate coinbases and thus other than starting
    2323                 :            :     // with the 2 existing duplicate coinbase pairs, not possible to create overwriting txs.  But by the
    2324                 :            :     // time BIP34 activated, in each of the existing pairs the duplicate coinbase had overwritten the first
    2325                 :            :     // before the first had been spent.  Since those coinbases are sufficiently buried it's no longer possible to create further
    2326                 :            :     // duplicate transactions descending from the known pairs either.
    2327                 :            :     // If we're on the known chain at height greater than where BIP34 activated, we can save the db accesses needed for the BIP30 check.
    2328                 :            : 
    2329                 :            :     // BIP34 requires that a block at height X (block X) has its coinbase
    2330                 :            :     // scriptSig start with a CScriptNum of X (indicated height X).  The above
    2331                 :            :     // logic of no longer requiring BIP30 once BIP34 activates is flawed in the
    2332                 :            :     // case that there is a block X before the BIP34 height of 227,931 which has
    2333                 :            :     // an indicated height Y where Y is greater than X.  The coinbase for block
    2334                 :            :     // X would also be a valid coinbase for block Y, which could be a BIP30
    2335                 :            :     // violation.  An exhaustive search of all mainnet coinbases before the
    2336                 :            :     // BIP34 height which have an indicated height greater than the block height
    2337                 :            :     // reveals many occurrences. The 3 lowest indicated heights found are
    2338                 :            :     // 209,921, 490,897, and 1,983,702 and thus coinbases for blocks at these 3
    2339                 :            :     // heights would be the first opportunity for BIP30 to be violated.
    2340                 :            : 
    2341                 :            :     // The search reveals a great many blocks which have an indicated height
    2342                 :            :     // greater than 1,983,702, so we simply remove the optimization to skip
    2343                 :            :     // BIP30 checking for blocks at height 1,983,702 or higher.  Before we reach
    2344                 :            :     // that block in another 25 years or so, we should take advantage of a
    2345                 :            :     // future consensus change to do a new and improved version of BIP34 that
    2346                 :            :     // will actually prevent ever creating any duplicate coinbases in the
    2347                 :            :     // future.
    2348                 :            :     static constexpr int BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT = 1983702;
    2349                 :            : 
    2350                 :            :     // There is no potential to create a duplicate coinbase at block 209,921
    2351                 :            :     // because this is still before the BIP34 height and so explicit BIP30
    2352                 :            :     // checking is still active.
    2353                 :            : 
    2354                 :            :     // The final case is block 176,684 which has an indicated height of
    2355                 :            :     // 490,897. Unfortunately, this issue was not discovered until about 2 weeks
    2356                 :            :     // before block 490,897 so there was not much opportunity to address this
    2357                 :            :     // case other than to carefully analyze it and determine it would not be a
    2358                 :            :     // problem. Block 490,897 was, in fact, mined with a different coinbase than
    2359                 :            :     // block 176,684, but it is important to note that even if it hadn't been or
    2360                 :            :     // is remined on an alternate fork with a duplicate coinbase, we would still
    2361                 :            :     // not run into a BIP30 violation.  This is because the coinbase for 176,684
    2362                 :            :     // is spent in block 185,956 in transaction
    2363                 :            :     // d4f7fbbf92f4a3014a230b2dc70b8058d02eb36ac06b4a0736d9d60eaa9e8781.  This
    2364                 :            :     // spending transaction can't be duplicated because it also spends coinbase
    2365                 :            :     // 0328dd85c331237f18e781d692c92de57649529bd5edf1d01036daea32ffde29.  This
    2366                 :            :     // coinbase has an indicated height of over 4.2 billion, and wouldn't be
    2367                 :            :     // duplicatable until that height, and it's currently impossible to create a
    2368                 :            :     // chain that long. Nevertheless we may wish to consider a future soft fork
    2369                 :            :     // which retroactively prevents block 490,897 from creating a duplicate
    2370                 :            :     // coinbase. The two historical BIP30 violations often provide a confusing
    2371                 :            :     // edge case when manipulating the UTXO and it would be simpler not to have
    2372                 :            :     // another edge case to deal with.
    2373                 :            : 
    2374                 :            :     // testnet3 has no blocks before the BIP34 height with indicated heights
    2375                 :            :     // post BIP34 before approximately height 486,000,000. After block
    2376                 :            :     // 1,983,702 testnet3 starts doing unnecessary BIP30 checking again.
    2377         [ +  - ]:     133976 :     assert(pindex->pprev);
    2378                 :     133976 :     CBlockIndex* pindexBIP34height = pindex->pprev->GetAncestor(params.GetConsensus().BIP34Height);
    2379                 :            :     //Only continue to enforce if we're below BIP34 activation height or the block hash at that height doesn't correspond.
    2380   [ -  +  +  + ]:     267952 :     fEnforceBIP30 = fEnforceBIP30 && (!pindexBIP34height || !(pindexBIP34height->GetBlockHash() == params.GetConsensus().BIP34Hash));
    2381                 :            : 
    2382                 :            :     // TODO: Remove BIP30 checking from block height 1,983,702 on, once we have a
    2383                 :            :     // consensus change that ensures coinbases at those heights cannot
    2384                 :            :     // duplicate earlier coinbases.
    2385   [ -  +  #  # ]:     133976 :     if (fEnforceBIP30 || pindex->nHeight >= BIP34_IMPLIES_BIP30_LIMIT) {
    2386   [ +  +  +  + ]:     285166 :         for (const auto& tx : block.vtx) {
    2387   [ +  +  +  + ]:     471983 :             for (size_t o = 0; o < tx->vout.size(); o++) {

    2580                 :            : 
    2581                 :            :     //! No need to periodic flush if at least this much space still available.
    2582                 :            :     static constexpr int64_t MAX_BLOCK_COINSDB_USAGE_BYTES = 10 * 1024 * 1024;  // 10MB
    2583                 :    1441722 :     int64_t large_threshold =
    2584                 :     720861 :         std::max((9 * nTotalSpace) / 10, nTotalSpace - MAX_BLOCK_COINSDB_USAGE_BYTES);

    3271                 :            :     // sanely for performance or correctness!
    3272                 :      59879 :     AssertLockNotHeld(::cs_main);
    3273                 :            : 
    3274                 :            :     // ABC maintains a fair degree of expensive-to-calculate internal state
    3275                 :            :     // because this function periodically releases cs_main so that it does not lock up other threads for too long
    3276                 :            :     // during large connects - and to allow for e.g. the callback queue to drain
    3277                 :            :     // we use m_chainstate_mutex to enforce mutual exclusion so that only one caller may execute this function at a time

    3465                 :            :     // running, as that could cause the tip to change while we disconnect
    3466                 :            :     // blocks.

    3470                 :            :     // callbacks to run. However, we should keep the block index in a
    3471                 :            :     // consistent state as we disconnect blocks -- in particular we need to

    3550                 :            :

    3559   [ #  #  #  # ]:          0 :         LOCK(cs_main);

    3562                 :          0 :             return false;
    3563                 :            :         }
    3564                 :            :

    3566                 :          0 :         to_mark_failed->nStatus |= BLOCK_FAILED_VALID;
    3567         [ #  # ]:          0 :         m_blockman.m_dirty_blockindex.insert(to_mark_failed);

    3569         [ #  # ]:          0 :         m_chainman.m_failed_blocks.insert(to_mark_failed);
    3570                 :            : 
    3571                 :            :         // If any new blocks somehow arrived while we were disconnecting
    3572                 :            :         // (above), then the pre-calculation of what should go into
    3573                 :            :         // setBlockIndexCandidates may have missed entries. This would
    3574                 :            :         // technically be an inconsistency in the block index, but if we clean
    3575                 :            :         // it up here, this should be an essentially unobservable error.
    3576                 :            :         // Loop back over all block index entries and add any missing entries
    3577                 :            :         // to setBlockIndexCandidates.
    3578         [ #  # ]:          0 :         for (auto& [_, block_index] : m_blockman.m_block_index) {

    4031                 :            :         }
    4032         [ -  + ]:     131804 :     }
    4033                 :            : 
    4034                 :            :     // Validation for witness commitments.
    4035                 :            :     // * We compute the witness hash (which is the hash including witnesses) of all the block's transactions, except the
    4036                 :            :     //   coinbase (where 0x0000....0000 is used instead).
    4037                 :            :     // * The coinbase scriptWitness is a stack of a single 32-byte vector, containing a witness reserved value (unconstrained).
    4038                 :            :     // * We build a merkle tree with all those witness hashes as leaves (similar to the hashMerkleRoot in the block header).
    4039                 :            :     // * There must be at least one output whose scriptPubKey is a single 36-byte push, the first 4 bytes of which are
    4040                 :            :     //   {0xaa, 0x21, 0xa9, 0xed}, and the following 32 bytes are SHA256^2(witness root, witness reserved value). In case there are
    4041                 :            :     //   multiple, the last one is used.
    4042         [ +  - ]:     133976 :     if (!CheckWitnessMalleation(block, DeploymentActiveAfter(pindexPrev, chainman, Consensus::DEPLOYMENT_SEGWIT), state)) {
    4043                 :          0 :         return false;
    4044                 :            :     }
    4045                 :            : 
    4046                 :            :     // After the coinbase witness reserved value and commitment are verified,
    4047                 :            :     // we can check if the block weight passes (before we've checked the
    4048                 :            :     // coinbase witness, it would be possible for the weight to be too
    4049                 :            :     // large by filling up the coinbase witness, which doesn't change
    4050                 :            :     // the block hash, so we couldn't mark the block as permanently
    4051                 :            :     // failed).
    4052         [ -  + ]:     133976 :     if (GetBlockWeight(block) > MAX_BLOCK_WEIGHT) {

    4101                 :            :         /* Determine if this block descends from any block which has been found
    4102                 :            :          * invalid (m_failed_blocks), then mark pindexPrev and any blocks between
    4103                 :            :          * them as failed. For example:
    4104                 :            :          *
    4105                 :            :          *                D3
    4106                 :            :          *              /
    4107                 :            :          *      B2 - C2
    4108                 :            :          *    /         \
    4109                 :            :          *  A             D2 - E2 - F2
    4110                 :            :          *    \
    4111                 :            :          *      B1 - C1 - D1 - E1
    4112                 :            :          *
    4113                 :            :          * In the case that we attempted to reorg from E1 to F2, only to find
    4114                 :            :          * C2 to be invalid, we would mark D2, E2, and F2 as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD
    4115                 :            :          * but NOT D3 (it was not in any of our candidate sets at the time).
    4116                 :            :          *
    4117                 :            :          * In any case D3 will also be marked as BLOCK_FAILED_CHILD at restart
    4118                 :            :          * in LoadBlockIndex.
    4119                 :            :          */

    4199                 :          0 : void ChainstateManager::ReportHeadersPresync(const arith_uint256& work, int64_t height, int64_t timestamp)
    4200                 :            : {
    4201                 :          0 :     AssertLockNotHeld(cs_main);
    4202                 :            :     {
    4203                 :          0 :         LOCK(cs_main);
    4204                 :            :         // Don't report headers presync progress if we already have a post-minchainwork header chain.
    4205                 :            :         // This means we lose reporting for potentially legitimate, but unlikely, deep reorgs, but
    4206                 :            :         // prevent attackers that spam low-work headers from filling our logs.
    4207   [ #  #  #  #  :          0 :         if (m_best_header->nChainWork >= UintToArith256(GetConsensus().nMinimumChainWork)) return;

    4208                 :            :         // Rate limit headers presync updates to 4 per second, as these are not subject to DoS
    4209                 :            :         // protection.
    4210                 :          0 :         auto now = std::chrono::steady_clock::now();

    4212                 :          0 :         m_last_presync_update = now;
    4213      [ #  #  # ]:          0 :     }
    4214                 :          0 :     bool initial_download = IsInitialBlockDownload();

    4684                 :            :             // overwritten. It corresponds to cases where the block-to-be-disconnect never had all its operations

    4970   [ +  +  -  + ]:     177368 :             } catch (const std::exception& e) {
    4971                 :            :                 // historical bugs added extra data to the block files that does not deserialize cleanly.
    4972                 :            :                 // commonly this data is between readable blocks, but it does not really matter. such data is not fatal to the import process.
    4973                 :            :                 // the code that reads the block files deals with invalid data by simply ignoring it.
    4974                 :            :                 // it continues to search for the next {4 byte magic message start bytes + 4 byte length + block} that does deserialize cleanly
    4975                 :            :                 // and passes all of the other block validation checks dealing with POW and the merkle root, etc...
    4976                 :            :                 // we merely note with this informational log message when unexpected data is encountered.
    4977                 :            :                 // we could also be experiencing a storage system read error, or a read of a previous bad write. these are possible, but
    4978                 :            :                 // less likely scenarios. we don't have enough information to tell a difference here.
    4979                 :            :                 // the reindex process is not the place to attempt to clean and/or compact the block files. if so desired, a studious node operator
    4980                 :            :                 // may use knowledge of the fact that the block files are not entirely pristine in order to prepare a set of pristine, and
    4981                 :            :                 // perhaps ordered, block files for later reindexing.

    5397                 :            : 
    5398                 :            :     // Cache percentages to allocate to each chainstate.
    5399                 :            :     //
    5400                 :            :     // These particular percentages don't matter so much since they will only be
    5401                 :            :     // relevant during snapshot activation; caches are rebalanced at the conclusion of
    5402                 :            :     // this function. We want to give (essentially) all available cache capacity to the
    5403                 :            :     // snapshot to aid the bulk load later in this function.
    5404                 :            :     static constexpr double IBD_CACHE_PERC = 0.01;
    5405                 :            :     static constexpr double SNAPSHOT_CACHE_PERC = 0.99;
    5406                 :            : 
    5407                 :            :     {
    5408                 :        804 :         LOCK(::cs_main);
    5409                 :            :         // Resize the coins caches to ensure we're not exceeding memory limits.
    5410                 :            :         //
    5411                 :            :         // Allocate the majority of the cache to the incoming snapshot chainstate, since
    5412                 :            :         // (optimistically) getting to its tip will be the top priority. We'll need to call
    5413                 :            :         // `MaybeRebalanceCaches()` once we're done with this function to ensure
    5414                 :            :         // the right allocation (including the possibility that no snapshot was activated

    5740                 :       1198 : }
    5741                 :            : 
    5742                 :            : // Currently, this function holds cs_main for its duration, which could be for
    5743                 :            : // multiple minutes due to the ComputeUTXOStats call. This hold is necessary
    5744                 :            : // because we need to avoid advancing the background validation chainstate
    5745                 :            : // farther than the snapshot base block - and this function is also invoked
    5746                 :            : // from within ConnectTip, i.e. from within ActivateBestChain, so cs_main is
    5747                 :            : // held anyway.
    5748                 :            : //
    5749                 :            : // Eventually (TODO), we could somehow separate this function's runtime from
    5750                 :            : // maintenance of the active chain, but that will either require
    5751                 :            : //
    5752                 :            : //  (i) setting `m_disabled` immediately and ensuring all chainstate accesses go
    5753                 :            : //      through IsUsable() checks, or
    5754                 :            : //
    5755                 :            : //  (ii) giving each chainstate its own lock instead of using cs_main for everything.
    5756                 :       1349 : SnapshotCompletionResult ChainstateManager::MaybeCompleteSnapshotValidation()

    5783                 :            :             "bad software modification that allowed an invalid snapshot to be "
    5784                 :            :             "loaded. As a result of this, the node will shut down and stop using any "
    5785                 :            :             "state that was built on the snapshot, resetting the chain height "
    5786                 :            :             "from %d to %d. On the next "
    5787                 :            :             "restart, the node will resume syncing from %d "
    5788                 :            :             "without using any snapshot data. "
    5789                 :            :             "Please report this incident to %s, including how you obtained the snapshot. "
    5790                 :            :             "The invalid snapshot chainstate will be left on disk in case it is "

    6190                 :            :     // indexed.

    6196         [ #  # ]:          0 :     if (chainstate.m_chain.Height() <= 0) {
    6197                 :          0 :         return {0, 0};

    6202                 :            :         // Leave the blocks in the background IBD chain alone if we're pruning
    6203                 :            :         // the snapshot chain.
    6204                 :          0 :         prune_start = *Assert(GetSnapshotBaseHeight()) + 1;
    6205                 :          0 :     }
    6206                 :            : 
    6207                 :          0 :     int max_prune = std::max<int>(
    6208                 :          0 :         0, chainstate.m_chain.Height() - static_cast<int>(MIN_BLOCKS_TO_KEEP));
    6209                 :            : 
    6210                 :            :     // last block to prune is the lesser of (caller-specified height, MIN_BLOCKS_TO_KEEP from the tip)
    6211                 :            :     //
    6212                 :            :     // While you might be tempted to prune the background chainstate more
    6213                 :            :     // aggressively (i.e. fewer MIN_BLOCKS_TO_KEEP), this won't work with index
    6214                 :            :     // building - specifically blockfilterindex requires undo data, and if
    6215                 :            :     // we don't maintain this trailing window, we hit indexing failures.
    6216                 :          0 :     int prune_end = std::min(last_height_can_prune, max_prune);
    6217                 :            : 
    6218                 :          0 :     return {prune_start, prune_end};
